Award.AwardTitle: Monte Carlo and Quasi-Monte Carlo Methods for Statistics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer simulations are used in virtually every branch of science and engineering, because some problems are simply beyond closed form mathematical solution, and because computers have become extremely fast. Against that trend, there is the constant feeling, and mathematical support, for the idea that strategically sampled values can give even better results than random ones do. Computer generated imaging is one of the largest users of simulations. Simulations of the behavior of light underly images from the economically significant motion picture and computer game industries, to problems of architectural rendering and scientific visualization. Many of the same ideas that go into choosing input points for simulations are also used to computerize difficult statistical decisions and to design industrial
products.

Quasi-Monte Carlo sampling is a method of producing inputs that are more evenly distributed than random points are. They are said to have low discrepancy. Most of the existing low discrepancy solutions are about placing points inside the unit cube. Some applications in computer rendering require samples from the triangle, simplex or other such spaces. Plain Monte Carlo sampling of those spaces is straightforward but low discrepancy sampling is quite different. The transformations that work for Monte Carlo may destroy the low discrepancy properties of the resulting points in the triangle. This project will develop low discrepancy sampling methods for the triangle and for tensor products of triangles. Factor analysis is about hundred years old, yet it remains problematic to even choose the number of factors to use in it. This project will develop cross-validatory methods to select the number of factors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work done under this project supported or partly supported 32 scholarly writings. Of those, 5 are PhD dissertations, and 19 are either published or accepted for publication. Others have been submitted for publication.   Several papers were about how to arrange samples of points inside triangles, spheres, balls and other such spaces so as to cover those objects as uniformly as mathematically possible.  One of the methods for triangles comes provably close to the mathematically best possible way to do it. Others were about how to determine the number of factors at work in a noisy data set.  Others were about how best to test whether a gene or collection of related genes has any association with a condition like a disease or surviving to a great age.  Others were about how to make such discoveries reliable and reproducible. Additional work was on how to predict the output of a computer model at points that have not yet been run, and how to measure the relative importance of all the inputs to a computer model.

The broader impacts of this work are varied.  The research on sampling within triangles and other such spaces is relevant to problems of graphical rendering, such as is used in the movie industry, computer games or scientific visualization.  Much of the work was on bioinformatics and potentially useful in medicine. For instance one paper found new genes associated with extreme longevity (living past 100).  Other papers looked at ways to test which genetic factors are associated with a disease. For instance, some of the data came from studies of Parkinson's disease and some from Duchenne muscular dystrophy. The work on computer models is motivated by industrial problems where engineers design products on the computer first before going to the laboratory or factory. The problem of counting the number of factors at work in a data set arises in psychology, economics and finance among other areas. Four PhD students that worked on this project are now employed as data scientists in US industry at Intel, AirBnB, Two Sigma and LinkedIn.  A fifth student is working on genomic science as a postdoc at the University of Pennsylvania.
